    A Series of Compounds Bearing a Dipyrido-Pyrimidine Scaffold Acting as Novel Human and Insect Pest Chitinase Inhibitors

    Abstract

    Chitinases not only play vital roles in the human innate immune system but are also essential for the development of pathogenic fungi and pests. Chitinase inhibitors are efficient tools to investigate the elusive role of human chitinases and to control pathogens and pests. Via hierarchical virtual screening, we have discovered a series of chitinase inhibitors with a novel scaffold that have high inhibitory activities and selectivities against human and insect chitinases. The most potent human chitotriosidase inhibitor, compound 40, exhibited a Ki of 49 nM, and the most potent inhibitor of the insect pest chitinase OfChi-h, compound 53, exhibited a Ki of 9 nM. The binding of these two most potent inhibitors was confirmed by X-ray crystallography. In a murine model of bleomycin-induced pulmonary fibrosis, compound 40 was found to suppress the chitotriosidase activity by 60%, leading to a significant increase in inflammatory cells and suggesting that chitotriosidase played a protective role.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The glycosyl hydrolase family 18 chitinases catalyze the degradation of chitin, a homopolymeric form of β-(1,4)-linked N-acetyl-D-glucosamine (GlcNAc). As chitin constitutes the cell wall of fungi, the eggshells of nematodes, and the exoskeleton of arthropods, chitinases play essential roles in the growth and development of chitin-containing organisms as well as immunologically defensive roles in non-chitin-containing organisms such as humans and plants.
    Humans have two chitinases: chitotriosidase (Chit1) and acidic mammalian chitinase (AMCase). A number of studies indicate that elevation of Chit1 in plasma or tissues is associated with several diseases. A 10- to 1000-fold elevation of Chit1 has been reported in the blood of patients with lysosomal storage diseases, such as Gaucher disease,(1) Niemann–Pick syndrome, and Fabry disease,(2) reflecting a particular activation state of macrophages.(3) Elevated levels of Chit1 are also observed in a variety of other diseases, including asthma and airway hyper-responsiveness,(4) infections (fungal and bacterial infection, malaria), chronic inflammation (atherosclerosis,(5) sarcoidosis(6)), liver diseases (nonalcoholic fatty liver disease steatohepatitis(7)), neurodegenerative diseases (Alzheimer’s disease, ischemic cerebrovascular dementia), and interstitial lung diseases in systemic sclerosis.(2) On the other hand, AMCase, which is distinguished from other chitinases by several unique features including a low optimum pH and the preference for the β-anomer of the substrate,(8) is highly expressed in the lung tissue of asthmatic patients and in animal models of asthma.(9−12) Moreover, it has been shown that AMCase is induced by a Th2-specific, IL-13-mediated pathway in a chitin or ovalbumin (OVA) allergy model.(10) Furthermore, it has been observed that treatment of allergen-challenged mice with AMCase antisera or AMCase inhibitors alleviated primary features of allergic inflammation.(10,13−15) Although both human chitinases were the subject of a plethora of investigations in the last decade, the exact role of either Chit1 or AMCase has not yet been fully defined.
    Due to diverse functions of chitinases, chitinase inhibitors have a number of potential applications, including as chemical probes, immunomodulators, fungicides, and insecticides. Several classes of chitinase inhibitors have been reported (Figure 1) including the pseudotrisaccharide allosamidin (1),(16) the cyclic dipeptide CI-4 (2),(17) the cyclic pentapeptides argifin (3) and argadin (4),(18) fully deacetylated chitooligosaccharides (5 and 6),(19) acetazolamide (7),(20) bisdionin C (8) and F (9),(13,21) methylxanthines,(22) theophylline (10), caffeine (11), pentoxifylline (12),(23) psammaplins (13),(24) and styloguanidines (14).(25) Many of these inhibitors are natural products. Some of the highly potent ones such as allosamidin, argifin, and argadin were employed to study the roles of Chit1 and AMCase in the development of various diseases.(10,14,26) However, their poor synthetic accessibility and low abundance in nature have so far hampered the widespread use of these inhibitors, whereas their structural complexity makes them unsuitable as starting points for drug design. Initial efforts to develop drug-like inhibitors of Chit1 and AMCase were based on the 1,3-dimethylxanthine scaffold and only resulted in weak inhibitors.(22,23) Synthesis of dicaffeine scaffold derivatives (named bisdionins, 8 and 9) with variable linker lengths produced moderately potent Chit1 and AMCase inhibitors.(13,21) Interestingly, one compound, bisdionin F (9) was found to be 20-fold selective for AMCase.(13) Another inhibitor discovery effort involving the combination of high-throughput screening, fragment-based drug design, and in silico screening led to the identification of an aminotriazole-based compound, Wyeth-1 (15), which was a moderately potent and non-selective Chit1 and AMCase inhibitor.(27) Using structure guided design, Wyeth-1 was later optimized into a highly potent AMCase inhibitor (16) with about 20-fold selectivity against Chit1. However, this compound was not pursued further due to safety concerns and dopamine receptor off-target activity.(15)
    Small-molecule drug-like inhibitors of human chitinases played a significant part in understanding their biological role and implications of inhibiting these proteins. However, investigations on the role of Chit1 and/or AMCase in the immune response are much more challenging. Apart from the design of suitable in vivo experiments, the specific inhibition of these proteins is required. All existing Chit1 or AMCase inhibitors are either not highly potent or lack selectivity toward these proteins and thus are not suitable to discriminate functional differences between Chit1 and AMCase. While the two most selective AMCase inhibitors are only 20-fold selective,(13,15) no human Chit1 selective inhibitor has been reported. Recently, a highly potent inhibitor (17) of mouse Chit1 has also been reported with about 143-fold selectivity against mouse AMCase, but its inhibitory effect on human Chit1 is not known.(28) In light of these circumstances, the development of novel, highly potent, highly selective, and in vivo active human Chit1 inhibitors is required.
    Besides studies on human chitinases, many researchers pay great attention to chitinases originating from pathogenic fungi and agricultural pests. This is because the chitinases essential for the development of fungi and pests are potential targets for developing drugs and agrochemicals. Chi-h, for example, is a lepidoptera-exclusive insect chitinase and is involved in cuticular chitin degradation during pest molting. Suppression of Chi-h activity results in severe defects in pupation and then death.
    Here, utilizing hierarchical virtual screening, we have identified a series of chitinase inhibitors with a common dipyrido-pyrimidine scaffold. A novel human Chit1-selective inhibitor with a Ki value of 49 nM and an insect pest Chi-h selective inhibitor with a Ki value of 9 nM were obtained. Cocrystal structures of both of these compounds with human Chit1 and chitinases from other species confirmed the binding and explained their potent activity and high selectivity. We further demonstrated the in vivo efficacy of most potent human Chit1-selective inhibitor using a murine model of bleomycin-induced pulmonary fibrosis, which suggested a protective role of Chit1 in inflammation under experimental conditions. Additionally, this study also provided lead compounds for the development of agrochemicals against destructive insect pests.

    Results

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Inhibitory Activities and Selectivities of the Compounds Obtained by SBVS

    Virtual screening to discover chitinase inhibitors led to the identification of nine compounds (Figure 2A and 18–26 in Table S1). The evaluation of inhibitory activities of these nine compounds against HsChit1 resulted in the identification of the compound 2-amino-1-(furan-2-ylmethyl)-5-oxo-3-(((tetrahydrofuran-2-yl)methyl)carbamoyl)-5H-dipyrido[1,2-a:2′,3′-d]pyrimidin-1-ium (24) that demonstrated almost complete inhibition of HsChit1 enzymatic activity (Figure 2B and Table S1). The three-dimensional overlay of the query ligand (GlcNAc)3 with 24 revealed a reasonable shape overlap even though the chemical structures of these two ligands are significantly different (Figure 2C,D). The concentration-dependent assay revealed a Ki value of 6.8 μM (Table 1). Further assessment against insect and bacterial chitinases revealed similar potencies against OfChi-h and SmChiB (Ki values of 8 and 6 μM, respectively).
    Table 1. Ki Values of 40 and 53 for Chitinases from Different Organisms
     Ki (μM)
    chitinase4053
    HsChit10.0491.12
    hAMCase3.969.72
    mChit10.0351.94
    mAMCase0.511.38
    OfChi-h0.390.009
    SmChiB0.410.058
    The dipyrido-pyrimidine-based scaffold represents a novel compound class with moderate activity, and to the best of our knowledge, this compound has not been previously described to possess activity against any chitinase. A similarity search against ChEMBL(29) and Similarity Ensemble Approach (SEA) database(30) using 24 as a query revealed no known biological activity for this class of compounds. Moreover, scanning of this compound for PAINS(31) and problematic compounds according to Eli Lilly MedChem Rules(32) exposed no major structural alert. The only warning given was the presence of a quaternary aryl nitrogen (Supporting Information). Although compounds with a quaternary aryl nitrogen may have some liabilities such as toxicities, we decided to pursue this scaffold for several reasons: (1) It is not predicted to interfere with assays, that is, passed the PAINS filter. (2) Several approved and marketed drugs contain a quaternary aryl nitrogen, for example, Ceftazidime (DrugBank code DB00438), pyridostigmine (DrugBank code DB00545), and berberine (DrugBank code DB04115). (3) The quaternary aryl nitrogen is present in a variety of natural products from marine sponges with antiviral and antitumor activities and acetylcholine esterase inhibitory activity.(33−35) (4) We wanted to develop this scaffold for a variety of uses such as biological probes and pesticides. Although 24 represents a novel and interesting chemical class with chitinase inhibitory activity, it is not potent enough to be used as a chemical probe or lead compound. However, 24 could be a suitable starting point for the development of highly potent, in vivo active inhibitor of HsChit1, insect or bacterial chitinases. Therefore, we decided to further improve the potency of the dipyrido-pyrimidine-based scaffold by identifying structural analogs. Seventy-five structural analogs of 24 were identified in two rounds of virtual screening (Figure 2A and 27–101 in Tables S2 and S3). The chemical structures of some of the relevant compounds are shown in Figure 3.
    The inhibitory potency of these structural analogs was tested against HsChit1, hAMCase, OfChi-h, and SmChiB. A majority of the tested analogs were found to be more potent than the parent compound 24 for all the tested enzymes (Tables S2 and S3). For HsChit1, 40 was found to be the most potent. It showed a Ki value of 49 nM, which was about 100-fold better than the parent compound 24 (Table 1). The specificity of 40 against another human chitinase, hAMCase, was also evaluated. Compound 40 inhibited hAMCase with a Ki value of 3.9 μM and was found to be 80-fold more potent against HsChit1 than hAMCase (Table 1). Evaluation of OfChi-h and SmChiB inhibitory activities revealed that 40 was also a broad-spectrum chitinase inhibitor with Ki values of 0.39 and 0.41 μM against OfChi-h and SmChiB, respectively. Apart from 40, compound 53 was another interesting compound displaying potent inhibition of OfChi-h and SmChiB enzymatic activities with Ki values of 9 and 58 nM, respectively. Unexpectedly, 53 showed weak activity against HsChit1 with Ki value of 1.12 μM (Table 1). The weak inhibition of 53 against HsChit1 suggested that the inhibitor might bind to HsChit1 by a different mechanism. The inhibitory activities of 40 and 53 were also measured against mouse Chit1 and AMCase. As expected, inhibitory activities of both 40 and 53 against mChit1 were similar to that of HsChit1 (Table 1). Interestingly, 40 was found to be only 15-fold more selective for mChit1 over mAMCase (Table 1).
    We next analyzed the structure activity relationships (SAR) to understand the mechanism of inhibition and functional groups responsible for higher potency and selectivity among the tested chitinases. The substituents were available at four positions of the dipyrido-pyrimidine-based scaffold (Figure S1). Among these 75 compounds, R2 and R3 positions were either unsubstituted or substituted with a methyl group. The comparison of a pair of compounds that differ only by the methyl group at the R2 or R3 position revealed no major differences in activity for a majority of the compounds (Figure S2). The major structural differences among these 75 analogs of 24 were in substituents at R1 and R4 positions. The effect of each of the substituents at R1 and R4 positions on chitinase enzymatic activity was analyzed by plotting the inhibition rates for compounds having a particular functional group (Figures S3 and S4). As shown in Figure S3, a majority of substituents have a carboxamide group at the R1 position, and the compounds without it (e.g., 36, 41, 44, 46, and 51) were found to be inactive for all the tested chitinases (see R1-11, R1-18, R1-19, and R1-24 in Figure S3). The carboxamide group may be involved in hydrogen bonding contacts with conserved active site residues. Further, substitutions of carboxamide linked with cycloalkyl groups, charged piperizine, and piperidine also led to reduced chitinase activity in a majority of the compounds (e.g., 27, 30, 42, 45, and 48) (see R1-14, R1-15, and R1-25 in Figure S3). In contrast to the substitution of non-aromatic groups, substitution of aromatic carboxamide moieties such as 4-methylbenzyl carboxamide (R1-1), benzyl carboxamide (R1-2), 3-pyridinylmethyl carboxamide (R1-3), 4-methoxybenzyl carboxamide (R1-4), 4-fluorobenzyl carboxamide (R1-5), and phenylethyl carboxamide (R1-7) at the R1 position resulted in higher inhibition in a majority of compounds. Among these, compounds with phenylethyl carboxamide and 3-pyridinylmethyl carboxamide at the R1 position, such as 40, 58, 91, 94, 96, 52, 53, 59, 67, and 99, were found to be the most potent for all the tested chitinases (Figure S3, Tables S2 and S3). In fact, a majority of the compounds with these two functional groups were active against HsChit1 and to some extent against other tested chitinases irrespective of substituents at other positions. It was interesting to see that compounds with 2-chlorobenzyl carboxamide (R1-9) at the R1 position (e.g., 69, 77, and 89) were either inactive or moderately active even though an aromatic ring at the R1 position was present. At the R1 position of the dipyrido-pyrimidine scaffold, SAR analysis suggests the requirement of functional groups that can make hydrogen bonding and stacking interactions. However, substitutions on the aromatic ring are not favorable especially at the ortho-position of the aromatic ring, which might be due to the limited size of that subpocket.
    SAR analysis of substituents at the R4 position revealed that all compounds with 3-pyridinylmethyl substitution (e.g., 36, 43, 44, and 45) did not possess chitinase inhibitory activity (Figure S4, Table S2) and were found to be inactive. Moreover, the compounds with alkyl substitutions such as butene, methoxyethyl, and methoxypropyl substitutions at the R4 position (e.g., 27, 48, 51, 56, 75, 88, and 93) were also either less active or inactive in most cases (Figure S4, Tables S2 and S3). Substitutions of benzyl (R4-1) and tetrahydrofuran (R4-2) at the R4 position resulted in higher HsChit1, hAMCase, and SmChiB inhibitory activities for a majority of compounds (e.g., 40, 47, 53, 61, 62, 91, 92, 94, 95, 96, and 99). Some substitutions at the R4 position were favorable for inhibition of only a specific chitinase. For example, compounds with 2-chlorobenzyl (R4-6) were only active against HsChit1 and possessed no inhibitory activity against hAMCase, OfChi-h, and SmChiB (Figure S4, Tables S2 and S3). Similarly, 4-fluorobenzyl (R4-3) substitution is not favorable for OfChi-h inhibition, while it is tolerable for hAMCase and SmChiB and to some extent for HsChit1. In addition to 2-chlorobenzyl (R4-6) and 4-fluorobenzyl (R4-3), substitution of benzyl (R4-1) at the R4 position also has a negative effect on OfChi-h inhibitory activity, which might be due to a smaller R4 group binding subpocket than the ones in HsChit1, hAMCase, and SmChiB.

    Crystal Complexes Reveal the Inhibitory Mechanism of Compound 40 against HsChit1 and SmChiB

    To further investigate the inhibitory mechanism of 40, it was cocrystallized with HsChit1-CAD. The structure of the HsChit1/40 complex was refined to 1.8 Å. The 2Fo-Fc map showed a clear electron density for 40 along the substrate-binding cleft. Crystallographic analysis demonstrated that the dipyrido-pyrimidine moiety of 40 binds at the +1 and +2 subsites of HsChit1. It is stacked between the indole groups of Trp99 and Trp218, forming strong hydrophobic interactions (Figure 4A). As these two residues are conserved not only in human chitinases but also in the other family 18 chitinases, a broad chitinase activity of the dipyrido-pyrimidine scaffold is expected. The carboxyl group of Asp213 forms a hydrogen bond with the 3-carbamoyl nitrogen atom. As Asp213 is conserved in all the tested chitinases (Figure S5), the interaction seems critical for the inhibitory activity. This may be the reason behind the lack of chitinase inhibitory activity in the case of compounds without carboxamide-based moieties at the R1 position. Water-mediated hydrogen bonds are formed between the guanidine group of Arg269, carboxyl group of Glu297, 2-amino nitrogen atom, and 3-carbamoyl oxygen atom as well as between the carboxyl group of Glu140 and 3-carbamoyl nitrogen atom. The phenylethyl carboxamide moiety at the R1 position of the dipyrido-pyrimidine scaffold inserts into a subpocket that is surrounded by Tyr267 and Trp358 and forms π–π interactions. As both aromatic amino acids are conserved in HsChit1, hAMCase, OfChi-h, and SmChiB, hydrophobic π–π stacking interactions seem critical for activity, and compounds lacking aromatic groups were not found to be active (Tables S2 and S3). Stacking interactions with Trp358 are especially important as Trp358 stacks with GlcNAc at the −1 subsite and is responsible for accommodating it in a boat conformation, which is critical for catalysis. Moreover, a benzyl at the R4 position stacks vertically with the indole group of Trp218 forming π–π T-shaped interactions. The details of the HsChit1/40 structural complex reveal that the strong π–π stacking interactions of the tryptophan at +1 and +2 subsites and hydrogen bonding with key residues around the active site make 40 a potent inhibitor against HsChit1.
    To understand the reason why 40 is a modest inhibitor against hAMCase, we tried to obtain a structure of the hAMCase/40 complex; unfortunately, both soaking and cocrystallization efforts were unsuccessful. Hence, to understand the HsChit1 selectivity of 40, a docking-predicted binding mode of 40 with hAMCase was analyzed and compared with the HsChit1/40 crystal structure (Figure S6). Compound 40 was predicted to bind at the +1 and +2 subsites of hAMCase and forms various π–π interactions with the residues around the active site similar to HsChit1. However, there were some subtle differences that might account for the selectivity of 40 for HsChit1. One critical difference may be the presence of His269 in hAMCase in place of Arg269 in HsChit1 even though the amino acid residues that form the binding pocket in both HsChit1 and hAMCase are highly conserved. In the case of the HsChit1/40 crystal structure, the guanidine group of Arg269 forms a water-mediated hydrogen bond with 40 and may be responsible for perfectly placing the phenylethyl ring for edge-to-face π stacking interactions with the conserved Trp358. In hAMCase, on the other hand, although this type of interaction is missing, the phenylethyl carboxamide moiety can still make hydrophobic contacts with residues Trp360, Trp31, and Tyr267. Moreover, the comparison of binding pocket volume of all available HsChit1 and hAMCase crystal structures revealed slightly a bigger binding pocket in the case of HsChit1, which may allow the rotation of functional groups for protein-ligand interactions (Figure S7A). Further, in the predicted binding mode, a benzyl ring at the R4 position of the dipyrido-pyrimidine scaffold is also not perfectly placed for edge-to-face π stacking interactions with another conserved residue Trp218. The distance between Trp99 and Trp218 in hAMCase is slightly longer than that in HsChit1 and might have contributed to the lower potency of 40 against hAMCase (Figure S7B).
    SmChiB was often used as a model to explore the binding mechanism. The crystal structure of SmChiB/40 also reveals a more or less similar binding mechanism to HsChit1 with a root-mean-square deviation of 1 Å (Figure 4B). Slight structural differences between the HsChit1 and SmChiB substrate binding sites might have caused the subtle differences in the 40 binding mode. The dipyrido-pyrimidine moiety is sandwiched between Trp97 and Trp220 (Trp99 and Trp218 in HsChit1) via the hydrophobic stacking interaction. The 3-carbamoyl nitrogen forms a hydrogen bond with the carboxyl group of Asp316, while the 2-amino nitrogen engages water-mediated hydrogen bonds with the carboxyl group of Asp215. The phenylethyl carboxamide moiety at the R1 position is located in a hydrophobic pocket consisting of Tyr214, Tyr292, and Trp403 side chains. The chitin insert domain of SmChiB covers the 1-benzyl ring though no subpocket interactions have been observed. The structural details reveal that, just like HsChit1, hydrogen bonds with Asp215 and hydrophobic stacking contacts with the dipyrido-pyrimidine moiety are also crucial for the inhibition of SmChiB enzymatic activity.

    Crystal Complexes Reveal the Inhibitory Mechanism of Compound 53 against HsChit1, OfChi-h, and SmChiB

    To investigate the binding mode of 53, the structures of HsChit1, OfChi-h, and SmChiB in complex with 53 were refined to 1.6, 2.2, and 2.5 Å, respectively (Figure 5). The active site reveals clear electron density for 53. Unexpectedly, the overall binding mode of 53 in OfChi-h is different from those of HsChit1 and SmChiB. One molecule of 53 occupies +1 and +2 subsites of OfChi-h, while electron density for two molecules of 53 was observed in HsChit1 and SmChiB +1 and +2 subsites. The OfChi-h/53 binding mode is more or less similar to HsChit1/40 and SmChiB/40, except the position of the 3-pyridinylmethyl carboxamide moiety, which extends toward the −1 subsite in close proximity to catalytic residues Asp306 and Glu308. The 3-pyridinyl nitrogen forms a hydrogen bond with the catalytic residue Glu308, and this particular interaction may be responsible for higher activity of 53 against OfChi-h. Other interactions are similar to HsChit1/40 and SmChiB/40 binding modes. The dipyrido-pyrimidine moiety is found to be sandwiched between Trp268 and Trp389 to form hydrophobic stacking interactions (Figure 5A). The 3-carbamoyl nitrogen atom forms a hydrogen bond with the side chain of Asp384. Moreover, the 1-tetrahydrofuran oxygen can form two hydrogen bonds with the side chain of Arg439 to stabilize this five-membered ring. All these stacking interactions and hydrogen bonds make 53 a potent inhibitor of OfChi-h.
    Contrary to the binding mode of 53 in OfChi-h, two 53 molecules occupying HsChit1 +1 and +2 subsites were observed (Figure 5B). The dipyrido-pyrimidine moieties were found sandwiched between Trp99 and Trp218. One molecule, the lower 53, inserts deeply into the substrate binding cleft closer to Trp99. Due to the deeper placement of the dipyrido-pyrimidine ring, a critical hydrogen bond between 3-pyridinyl nitrogen and catalytic residue Glu140 was not observed as the pyridine ring flips in another direction. Interestingly, the loss of this hydrogen bond is compensated by the hydrogen bonding interaction with the hydroxyl of Tyr212 and π–π stacking interactions with Trp358. The catalytic residue Glu140 instead interacts with the 3-carbamoyl moiety. Moreover, a water-molecule-mediated hydrogen bonding interaction between the 3-carbamoyl moiety and the backbone nitrogen of Trp99 was also observed. Additionally, the 5-carbonyl oxygen atom forms a hydrogen bond with the hydroxyl of Tyr141. The other molecule, upper 53, only forms stacking interactions with Trp218 and one hydrogen bond between 3-pyridine and the backbone carbonyl oxygen atom of Trp218. The hydrophobic stacking interactions of the four-layer sandwich structure stabilize the upper 53 molecule. The distance between the indole group of Trp99 and the dipyrido-pyrimidine ring of the lower 53 is 3.5 Å, the same distance that is between the indole group of Trp218 and the dipyrido-pyrimidine ring of the upper 53 and between the two 53 dipyrido-pyrimidine rings. The +1 subsite Trp99 migrates downward 1.5 Å to accommodate these two molecules. The unfavorable Gly98-Thr103 main chain conformational change is consistent with the decreased inhibitor activity.
    The asymmetric unit comprised two molecules of SmChiB/53, of which the inhibitor binding mode of each protein molecule is different (Figure 5C). Two 53 were bound in +1 and +2 subsites of one protein molecule; however, the other protein molecule accommodates only one 53. In the case where two 53 occupy +1 and +2 subsites, the lower 53 3-pyridinyl nitrogen atom forms a strong hydrogen bond with the oxygen atom of the catalytic residue Glu144 side chain. The tetrahydrofuran group at the R4 position is located near the chitin insert domain, and its oxygen atom forms a hydrogen bond with the side chain of Asp215. Additionally, the lower inhibitor engages two water-mediated hydrogen bonds, and the 3-carbamoyl nitrogen and oxygen form hydrogen bonds with the side chain of Asp316 and the backbone of Trp97, respectively. The upper inhibitor is only stabilized by hydrophobic stacking interactions between the lower 53 and Trp220. The two-molecule insertion causes a large conformational change where the distance between Trp97 and Trp220 increases from 7.5 to 10 Å. Unlike the two-molecule inhibitor binding mode, binding of the one-molecule inhibitor almost has no influence on the distance between +1 and +2 subsite residues. This binding mechanism is similar to that of OfChi-h/53 where 3-carbamoyl nitrogen forms a hydrogen bond with the side chain of Asp215 and 3-pyridinyl nitrogen forms a hydrogen bond with Glu144. The 2-amino and 3-carbonyl also form water-mediated hydrogen bonds with carboxyl of Asp316 and backbone amide nitrogen of Trp97, respectively. This suggests that 53 inhibits SmChiB by two mechanisms. The inhibitor inserts into +1 and +2 subsites by two-molecule mode at high concentration, while the inhibitor inserts by one-molecule mode at low concentration. The details of the crystal structure complex are consistent with increased inhibitory activity of 53.
    Although the binding of two molecules of 53 with HsChit1 and SmChiB at +1 and +2 subsites is peculiar, it has been previously observed in several chitinase crystal structures.(36) To further study the binding mode of 53, isothermal titration calorimetry (ITC) experiments were performed to determine the binding stoichiometry of 53 with HsChit1, OfChi-h, and SmChiB in solution. The Kd values for 53 derived from the ITC experiment are in agreement with Ki values from the chitinase inhibition assay (Tables 1 and 2 and Figure S8). Binding of 53 to OfChi-h comprises mainly of hydrogen bond and hydrophobic contacts as indicated by negative or favorable ΔH and ΔS values. On the other hand, binding of 53 to both HsChit1 and SmChiB involves conformational changes as indicated by positive or unfavorable entropy values. Moreover, the thermodynamic data (ΔH and ΔS) expose similar binding mode of 53 to HsChit1 and SmChiB. This observation is consistent with our HsChit1/53 and SmChiB/53 crystal structures where a conformational change facilitates the binding of the second molecule. However, further analysis of ITC data revealed a stoichiometry of ∼1 for the number of 53 bound per enzyme molecule. The ITC results indicated the binding of only one 53 molecule to both HsChit1 and SmChiB. The differences in ITC and HsChit1/53 and SmChiB/53 crystal structures might be due to different experimental conditions as much higher concentrations of 53 were used to grow crystals.

    Bleomycin Challenge Increases Chit1 Expression

    To test the in vivo efficacy of 40, a well-established model of lung fibrosis was used, in which mice were intranasally sensitized with bleomycin. Eight days after the last of the three challenge doses were administered, the expression of Chit1 in the lung tissue was increased 3-fold and the chitinase activity of the bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF) was also increased (Figure 6). Since this time point is at the early stage of pulmonary fibrosis, the expressions of collagen gene Col3 and essential cytokines during pathogenesis, including Areg and TGFb, were at similar levels in the bleomycin-challenged and control groups. As type 2 inflammation is involved in pulmonary fibrosis, leukocyte and gene expression of cytokines were also detected. In tissues (Figure 7), bleomycin did not have a significant impact on the total cell, eosinophil, neutrophil, monocyte, alveolar macrophage or interstitial macrophage numbers, or gene expression of the type 2 cytokines IL-5 and IL-13. The gene for type 2 initiators, Il33, was expressed at similar levels in both groups of mice. Bleomycin administration also had no significant impact on the total cell, eosinophil, neutrophil, and alveolar macrophage or interstitial macrophage numbers in the BALF at day 12. These data suggested that bleomycin increased Chit1 expression and chitinase activity in lung tissue before pulmonary immunity.

    Suppression of Chitinase Activity Enhances Lung Inflammation Induced by Tissue Damage

    The mice were treated with bleomycin in the presence/absence of 40. The chitinase activity in the BALF of these mice was then compared (Figure 8). Administration of bleomycin alone induced an increase of chitinase activity by 40% compared with that of the control group; however, administration of bleomycin combined with 40 completely suppressed this elevation. In an in vitro assay, the addition of 10 μg of 40 and 1 μg of 40 reduced the chitinase activity in the BALF by 55 and 35%, respectively, suggesting that the suppression by 40 was dosage-dependent.
    The impact of suppressing the chitinase activity was further investigated. In comparison with the bleomycin-treated groups, treatment with bleomycin combined with 40 did not alter the gene expression levels of Chit1 and fibrosis cytokines or the amount of type 2 inflammation cytokines but did increase the number of macrophage cells in the lungs, including monocytes, PD-L2+ alveolar macrophages and interstitial macrophages, and the expression level of the cytokine Areg in the lungs. This increase in the number of macrophage cells suggests that suppression of chitinase activity induced immunological responses. As Areg is a well-known epidermal growth factor that plays an essential role in the pathogenesis of pulmonary fibrosis, up-regulation of Areg is a sign of fibrosis.
    To confirm that 40 would have a similar activity against mChit1, inhibitory activities of 40 against mChit1 and mAMCase were determined in vitro (Table 1). As expected, 40 showed a similar activity against mChit1 as against the human enzyme with a Ki value of 35 nM and about 15-fold selectivity between mChit1 and mAMCase.
    Additionally, 40 was tested against a selected set of key enzymes, transporters, and ion channels to characterize the activity profile.(37) These include protein-tyrosine kinase (LCK), phosphodiesterase (PDE4D), cyclooxygenase (COX2), acetylcholinesterase (ACHE), monoamine oxidase (MAO-A), steroid nuclear receptors (GR), 5-hydroxytyramine transporter (5HTT), and K+ channel (hERG). Compound 40 displayed no significant inhibitory activity against the majority of the proteins (Table S4). However, 40 showed potential cardiotoxicity (98.8% inhibition at 10 μM for hERG) and revealed inhibition of the phosphodiesterase enzyme (87.8% inhibition at 10 μM for PDE4D2). This is concerning and should be addressed before further development of 40 for therapeutic purposes. Moreover, even though 40 inhibits mChit1 with high potency, it is not possible to completely exclude a scenario where inhibition of other proteins such as mAMCase might have contributed to the increase in inflammation, especially when 40 is only 15-fold selective for mChit1 as compared to 80-fold selectivity for HsChit1.

    Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Structure-based virtual screening facilitated the identification of the dipyrido-pyrimidine-based scaffold that exhibited inhibitory activity against chitinases from various species such as humans, insects, and bacteria (Table 1). Among the dipyrido-pyrimidine derivatives, 40 was found to be the most potent HsChit1 inhibitor, and to the best of our knowledge, 40 is the most potent synthetic HsChit1 inhibitor reported to date. Natural products allosamidin (1) and demethylallosamidin are the only known HsChit1 inhibitors that are more potent than 40.(33) However, their use in drug discovery was significantly impeded by their limited availability, difficulty in synthesis, and pharmacokinetic properties not suitable for in vivo studies. Furthermore, 40 demonstrated high selectivity against hAMCase and is the most selective HsChit1 inhibitor known to date. Recently, a highly potent inhibitor of mouse Chit1 (17) with 143-fold selectivity against mAMCase has also been reported, but its inhibitory effect on HsChit1 is not known.(28) The dipyrido-pyrimidine-based scaffold possessed broad chitinase inhibitory activity and also inhibited chitinases from insect pests and bacteria with high potency. Compound 53 was especially interesting, inhibiting OfChi-h and SmChiB with potency in the low nM range. Importantly, this compound was only a weak inhibitor of HsChit1, making it an excellent candidate for agrochemical development.
    Binding of the most potent compounds 40 and 53 was confirmed by X-ray crystallography, and several crystal structures of human, insect, and bacterial chitinases were obtained in complex with these dipyrido-pyrimidine ligands, providing structural insight into the inhibitory mode and selectivity. Crystal structures revealed that both compounds bind to various chitinases in a similar binding mode forming similar interactions. The stacking interaction with two tryptophans at +1 and +2 subsites is the main driving force behind the binding of the dipyrido-pyrimidine scaffold to various chitinases, while substitutions at R1 and R4 positions control the potency and selectivity. Although compounds binding to both −n and +n subsites have previously been observed,(13,33,34) dipyrido-pyrimidine ligands specifically bind to +1 and +2 subsites with functional groups extending toward the active site. This type of binding mode was not described previously in the literature and suggests a new subpocket to target for the development of highly potent inhibitors of family 18 chitinases.
    Comparison of the cocrystal structures of HsChit1/40 and docking-predicted binding mode of 40 in the hAMCase binding pocket allowed us to elucidate the mechanism leading to the 80-fold selectivity of 40 for HsChit1 over hAMCase. Although the amino acid residues that form the binding pocket in both HsChit1 and hAMCase are highly conserved, the R269H substitution in hAMCase, which is one of the two different residues (the other is M300I in hAMCase) near the catalytic site may be responsible for the higher selectivity of 40 for HsChit1. SAR analysis suggested that all active compounds bear substituents with hydrogen bonding capabilities at R4 positions, which interact with residues in the vicinity. These interactions facilitated much favorable placement of the dipyrido-pyrimidine ring and other aromatic moieties for stronger π–π stacking with tryptophans not only at positive subsites but also near the catalytic subpocket. Reduction in overall protein-ligand contacts in hAMCase might have contributed to comparatively lower binding affinity of dipyrido-pyrimidine ligands against hAMCase. Our SAR analysis and comparison of crystal and docked 40 structures further provided guidelines for the development of hAMCase-selective compounds. It has been shown previously that a hydrophobic group facing the positively charged side chain of Arg269 in HsChit1 could have a negative effect on potency, whereas these groups can form van der Waals contacts with the hAMCase His269 imidazole ring.(15) Hence, to develop hAMCase-selective dipyrido-pyrimidine ligands, substitution of moieties such as ethylbenzyl carboxamide and propylbenzyl carboxamide at the R1 position could be preferred. Moreover, since the R1 group binding subpocket is slightly smaller in HsChit1, substitutions at the meta-position of the benzyl ring could be helpful in developing hAMCase-selective compounds.
    The cocrystal structures of 53 with OfChi-h, HsChit1, and SmChiB outlined the unique binding mode of this compound. Binding of 53 to OfChi-h was similar to those of HsChit1/40 and SmChiB/40 cocrystal structures with one molecule in +1 and +2 subsites. The dipyrido-pyrimidine moiety of 53 was found to occupy a similar position. However, the presence of a donor in the 3-pyridinyl moiety triggered the hydrogen bond formation with catalytic glutamate, which might be responsible for its high binding affinity against OfChi-h. The crystal structure of SmChiB/53 was a peculiar case as both types of binding modes were observed in each of the two SmChiB molecules in the asymmetric unit. The observation of two different binding modes in one enzyme suggests a concentration-dependent inhibitory mechanism.
    The discovery of 40 enabled us to understand the dynamic roles of Chit1 in inflammation by partially suppressing the activity of Chit1. In a bleomycin-induced lung fibrosis murine model, Chit1–/– mice appeared to have significantly reduced lung fibrosis, indicating that 100% suppression of Chitl protects mice from severe lung fibrosis. As indicated by inhibitory evaluation, 40 inhibited the chitinase activity of BALF by 50% in vivo compared with the elevated level of Chit1 induced by bleomycin. This attenuated level, which was comparable to that of bleomycin-untreated mice, led to a significant increase in inflammatory cells and factors. In our murine model, bleomycin treatment induced elevated expression levels of Chit1, but not collagen and fibrosis cytokine, type 2 inflammation initiator IL-33, and inflammation cytokines IL-5 and IL-13. These results indicated that Chit1 was one of the initiators to respond to bleomycin treatment. Partial suppression of Chit1 leading to inflammation suggested that Chit1 played a protective role. However, the possibility that the increased inflammation is due to the inhibition of other proteins such as AMCase could not be excluded. Moreover, as inflammation is a very complex process with multiple triggers, effectors, and mechanisms, the observed outcome (destructive or protective) may depend on several factors such as experiment design, dose, and method of administration, exposure duration, and markers. Therefore, additional investigations using 40 as a tool compound are required to determine the exact role of Chit1, destructive or protective. Based on our observations, we hypothesize that the homeostasis level of Chit1 under disease conditions determines its protective or destructive role and will be investigated in the future using tool compounds such as 40.
    Our study resulted in the identification of compounds containing the dipyrido-pyrimidine scaffold with inhibitory activities against chitinases from human, insects, and bacteria. Among the reported dipyrido-pyrimidine derivatives, 40 and 53 are reasonably potent and selective against HsChit1 and OfChi-h, respectively, and could be used as starting points for the development of useful tools for human therapy and pest controls. However, separate optimization efforts are needed for their utility as therapeutics or pesticides. For optimization efforts targeted toward therapeutics, safety is the most important factor. Since 40 showed inhibitory activities against hERG and PDE4D2, derivatives of 40 should be assessed not only for inhibition of human chitinases but also for their off-target activities. Although 40 does not violate Lipinski’s rule of five,(38) properties such as molecular weight and log P are toward the higher end and should be either reduced or maintained during optimization. Efforts should also be made to improve the solubility of compounds for oral bioavailability. Safety is also the most important factor in the development of pesticides, and future development efforts should be focused on improving the selectivity toward insect chitinase while avoiding any activity against human chitinase and other human and animal proteins. Cocrystal structures of 53 with both HsChit1 and OfChi-h and differences in the active site can be exploited to improve selectivity. In addition, hydrophobicity of the dipyrido-pyrimidine scaffold should be maintained or improved during optimization as most pesticides are nonpolar hydrophobic molecules. Moreover, high water solubility is not a desired characteristic for the pesticide development due to the low soil adsorption coefficient and risk of polluting the ground water.
    In summary, by utilizing a combination of in silico, in vitro and in vivo experiments, we have discovered and validated a chemical scaffold, which potently inhibited chitinases from humans, insects, and bacteria. Combining X-ray crystallography and computational modeling, we further revealed the molecular basis of inhibition and selectivity. The identified scaffold can be utilized to develop highly efficient and selective molecular tools to regulate chitinase, which is vital in human immunity, pathogenic fungi, and pest insect development.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Structure-Based Virtual Screening

    Structure-based virtual screening (SBVS) was carried out following a hierarchical virtual screening protocol,(39) which is summarized in Figure 2A. Initially, a library of about 4 million commercially available compounds was filtered based on their shape and electrostatic potential similarities with three units of β-1,4-linked N-acetylglucosamine, (GlcNAc)3. The bioactive conformation of (GlcNAc)3 was used as a query for shape and electrostatic comparisons (PDB code: 3WL1). The shape similarity calculations were performed using the ROCS program.(40) Ligand conformations for shape similarity calculations were generated employing the Omega program.(41) A maximum number of 200 conformations were generated for each compound. TanimotoCombo, a combined Tanimoto coefficient(42) for the shape and chemical features, was used to rank-order the screening library. The 1000 top-ranked compounds in their ROCS-aligned conformations were then subjected to electrostatic potential comparisons using the EON program. The MMFF force field(43−47) was used to add partial charges to the compounds. Similarity was assessed using a combined shape and electrostatic similarity metric (ET_Combo score). The top-ranking 500 compounds were then selected for further prioritization using molecular docking based on their interactions with the active site. Molecular docking was performed using the Glide program.(48−50) Ligands for molecular docking were prepared using LigPrep from Schrödinger. Ionization and tautomeric states of compounds were generated at a target pH of 7.0 ± 2.0 using the Epik program.(51,52) The protein structure for molecular docking was prepared using protein preparation utility in Maestro (Schrödinger Inc.) where hydrogens were added, bond orders were assigned, and protonation states of all charged residues were determined at the neutral pH. The grid for molecular docking was generated using the coordinates of (GlcNAc)3 bound to OfCht1 (PDB code: 3WL1). Glide “docking score”, which is a Glide score with Epik penalties, was used as a scoring function to rank-order compounds. The compound ranking for each method in the hierarchical virtual screening protocol is given in Table S5. In addition, the 2D similarity between (GlcNAc)3 and hit compounds using MACCS keys was also performed. The low Tanimoto scores for all hit compounds highlighted the importance of a hierarchical virtual screening protocol since a simple 2D similarity search would not yield comparable results. About 50 high-scoring compounds were visually inspected, and out of these, a set of 10 compounds were then cherry-picked to test their ability to block hydrolysis of substrate 4MU-β-(GlcNAc)2 to 4-MU and (GlcNAc)2 using a fluorometric assay. Out of these 10 selected compounds, one compound was not available commercially. After identifying the initial actives, two more rounds of virtual screening were carried out to identify structural analogs. A similar protocol to the first round was used in two subsequent rounds (Figure 2A). The most active compound from each round was selected as a query for the shape and electrostatic similarity search. In addition, a substructure search was also used in the third round to identify structural analogs. Compound ranking for the second-round hits is given in Table S6. Ranking was not employed to select compounds in the third round, and emphasis was given to compounds similar to the most potent ones in the previous round. Diversity and compound selection based on SAR exploration were also considered. Evaluation of the initial hit and its derivatives for PAINS(31) and problematic compounds according to Eli Lilly MedChem Rules(32) was performed using the Filter program from OpenEye Scientific Software and a ruby implementation of Eli Lilly MedChem Rules. Molecular docking of 40 to the AMCase crystal structure (PDB code: 3RM8) was carried out using the Glide program. Ligand and protein structures were prepared using the ligand and protein structure preparation utility of Maestro (Schrödinger Inc.) at a target pH of 2.0.

    Chemicals

    Compounds were purchased from Topscience (http://www.tsbiochem.com), a local distributor of compounds from chemical vendors including Chembridge, Chemdiv, and Vitas-M. The purities of these compounds were verified to be >95%. All of the compounds were maintained as DMSO stock solutions.

    Enzyme Preparation

    Human chitotriosidase catalytic domain (HsChit1-CAD), human acidic mammalian chitinase catalytic domain (hAMCase-CAD), mouse chitotriosidase catalytic domain (mChit1), mouse acidic mammalian chitinase catalytic domain (mAMCase-CAD), and Ostrinia furnacalis chitinase h (OfChi-h) were overexpressed in Pichia pastoris, and SmChiB was overexpressed in Escherichia coli BL21 (DE3). The target proteins were purified using metal-chelating chromatography as described previously.(19) All of the expressed proteins were quantified using a BCA protein assay kit (TaKaRa Biotech, China) with bovine serum albumin as the standard. The purity of these enzymes was analyzed by sodium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE) and found to be >95% in all cases.

    Chitinase Inhibition Assay and Ki Determination

    The chitinolytic activities of HsChit1-CAD, hAMCase-CAD, mChit1-CAD, mAMCase-CAD, OfChi-h, and SmChiB were determined using 4-methylumbelliferyl β-D-N,N′-diacetylchitobioside hydrate (4MU-(GlcNAc)2) (provided by Prof. Jianjun Zhang of China Agricultural University) as the substrate. The reaction mixture consisted of 100 μL of 10 nM testing enzyme, 50 μM 4MU-(GlcNAc)2, 10 μM inhibitor, 1% DMSO, and 0.1% Triton X-100 in 20 mM sodium phosphate buffer (pH 6.0). The reaction mixture in the absence of compounds was used as a blank control. After incubation at 30 °C for 30 min, 0.5 M sodium carbonate was added to stop the reaction, and the fluorescence produced by the released 4-MU was quantified with a Varioskan Flash microplate reader (Thermo Fisher Scientific) using excitation and emission wavelengths of 360 and 440 nm, respectively. Experiments were performed in triplicate unless otherwise specified. For the determination of Ki, the substrate concentration was set at 50, 30, and 15 μM. The inhibitor concentration varied according to the inhibition activity. Ki values were obtained by curve fitting using Prism software (GraphPad).

    Cocrystallization and Data Collection

    HsChit1-CAD, OfChi-h, and SmChiB were crystallized as described previously.(53−55) Briefly, HsChit1-CAD was concentrated to 9 mg/mL in 10 mM HEPES (pH 7.5) and 50 mM NaCl. Then the enzyme was incubated with 40 or 53 at a ratio of 1:10 at 277 K for 12 h. Crystals were grown by the hanging-drop vapor-diffusion method at 293 K by mixing 1 μL of the protein solution and an equal volume of a well solution containing 25% (w/v) polyethylene glycol (PEG) 3350 and 0.2 M potassium sodium tartrate (PST) at pH 7.2. OfChi-h incubated with 53 was spin-concentrated to 10 mg/mL in 20 mM bis-Tris (pH 6.5) containing 50 mM NaCl. The hanging-drop vapor-diffusion crystallization experiments were set up by mixing 1 μL of OfChi-h and 1 μL of reservoir solution containing 100 mM HEPES pH 7.0 and 30% (w/v) Jeffamine ED-2001. SmChiB was incubated with a 10-fold molar excess of 40 or 53. For crystallization, 1 μL of 20 mg/mL protein solution was mixed with an equal volume of a well solution containing 50 mM citrate (pH 5.6), 0.5 M Li2SO4, and 0.25 M (NH4)2SO4. Crystals appeared within 1–2 weeks at 293 K. Afterward, the crystals were soaked for 10 s in a reservoir solution containing 10% (v/v) glycerol as a cryoprotectant and subsequently flash-cooled in liquid nitrogen. The X-ray diffraction data of the complexes were collected on the BL-19 U1 at Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility in China. The diffraction data of the complexes were processed using the HKL-3000 package.

    Structure Determination and Refinement

    The structures of HsChit1/40 (PDB code: 6JJR), HsChit1/ 53 (PDB code: 6JK6), OfChi-h/53 (PDB code: 6JMN), SmChiB/40 (PDB code: 6JK9), and SmChiB/53 (PDB code: 6JKF) were solved by molecular replacement with Phaser.(56) The PHENIX suite of programs was used for structure refinement.(57) Coot was used to manually build and extend the molecular models.(58) The quality of the models was checked by PROCHECK.(59) Structural figures were generated using PyMOL. The statistics of the diffraction data and structure refinement are summarized in Table 3.

    Isothermal Titration Calorimetry

    HsChit1, SmChiB, and OfChi-h were desalted into ITC buffer (50 mM NaH2PO4, 150 mM NaCl, pH 6.0). Compound 53 was dissolved in the same buffer. Measurements of HsChit1 were conducted at 25 °C with a stirring speed of 1000 rpm. After the baseline was balanced, 2.5 μL of 1 mM 53 was injected into a calorimeter cell containing 100 μM HsChit1. The injections were repeated 16 times over 180 s intervals. The background was measured by injecting the inhibitor into the cell containing only buffer. ITC experiments with SmChiB or OfChi-h were performed as described for HsChit1 but with different proteins and inhibitor concentrations (40 μM SmChiB, 400 μM 53 or 10 μM OfChi-h, 100 μM 53). After subtracting the blank, the integrated heat of injection was used to fit one site binding model using Microcal Origin 7.0. Gibbs free energy (ΔG) and the entropy change (ΔS) can be calculated from the enthalpy change (ΔH) and the binding constant K using ΔG = −RT ln K and ΔG = ΔH – TΔS.

    Selectivity Profile

    The selectivity profile of 40 against a subset of proteins selected from the early in vitro mini safety panel of WuXi AppTec was measured by the vendor according to published protocols.(37)

    Biological Methods (in Vivo)

    All experiments were approved by the Animal Care and Use Committee of RIKEN and were performed in accordance with institutional guidelines.

    Cell Preparation and Flow Cytometry

    Lung and bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF) cells were prepared as described previously.(60) Briefly, lungs were minced with scissors and incubated with 10% FBS/RPMI-1640 containing 50 μg/mL Liberase TM (Roche, Basel, Switzerland) and 1 μg/mL DNase I (Roche) for 1 h at 37 °C. Digested lung tissue was homogenized with GentleMACS (Miltenyi Biotec) and then passed through a strainer. After density-gradient centrifugation using a 30% (v/v) Percoll solution (GE Healthcare), cells were used for flow cytometric analysis. BALF cells were collected by washing the lungs thrice with 500 μL of PBS. For flow cytometric analysis, FITC-conjugated anti-Gr-1 (RB6-8C5), Alexa647-conjugated anti-Siglec-F (E50-2440), PE-Cy7-conjugated anti-CD11c (HL3), BV421-conjugated anti-CD11b (M1/70), and V500-conjugated anti-CD45 (30-F11) antibodies were purchased from BD Biosciences. PE-conjugated anti-PD-L2 (TY25) and APC-Cy7-conjugated anti-F4/80 (BM8) antibodies were purchased from Biolegend. Lung and BALF cells were analyzed: CD45+SiglecF+CD11clo cells as eosinophils, CD45+ CD11b+ Gr1hi cells as neutrophils, CD45+ Autofluorescence+SiglecF+CD11chi cells as alveolar macrophages, CD45+Autofluorescence+SiglecFloF4/80+ cells as interstitial macrophages, and CD45+ Autofluorescence-MHC classII+CD11b+ Gr1lo as monocytes.

    Bleomycin-Induced Inflammation and Challenge

    All experiments used 8 week old female C57BL6/N mice from Charles River. Mice were intranasally (i.n.) administered with 6 μg/mouse bleomycin for 3 consecutive days. Compound 40 or vehicle (5% DMSO in PBS) was intraperitoneally (i.p.) administered from day 0 to day 11 at 2 μg/mouse. Necropsies were performed 24 h after the final challenge (day 12).

    Quantitative Polymerase Chain Reaction (qPCR)

    Total RNA was extracted from lung tissue using the TRIzol reagent (Thermo Fischer Scientific), and cDNA was synthesized with the SuperScript III First-Strand Synthesis System for RT-PCR (Sigma). qPCR was carried out using an SYBR Premix Ex Taq II (Tli RNase H Plus, Takara Bio) on a StepOne Plus Real-Time PCR System qPCR instrument (Applied Biosystems) using the following primers: Chit1, forward 5′-TGACTCTGCTGATGGTCCAG-3′ and reverse 5′-TAGGCTGTTCAGCTCCTGGT-3′; Col3, forward 5′-TCTCTAGACTCATAGGACTGACC-3′ and reverse 5′-TTCTTCTCACCCTTCTTCATCC-3′; Areg, forward 5′-GGTCTTAGGCTCAGGCCATTA-3′ and reverse 5′-CGCTTATGGTGGAAACCTCTC-3′; Tgfb, forward 5′-CACCTGCAAGACCATCGACAT-3′ and reverse 5′-GAGCCTTAGTTTGGACAGGATCTG-3′; Il33, forward 5′- CCTTCTCGCTGATTTCCAAG-3′ and reverse 5′-CCGTTACGGATATGGTGGTC-3′; Il5, forward 5′-AGCAATGAGACGATGAGGCT-3′ and reverse 5′-CCCACGGACAGTTTGATTC-3′; Il13, forward 5′-TGTGTCTCTCCCTCTGACCC-3′ and reverse 5′-TCCAGGGCTACACAGAACCC-3′; and internal control β-actin, forward 5′-ACTATTGGCAACGAGCGGTTC-3′ and reverse 5′-GGATGCCACAGGATTCCATAC-3′. Data were normalized against β-actin by the ΔΔCt method.

    Chit1 Activity Assay

    10 μL of BALF and supernatants of cultured cells were incubated with 10 μL of 0.5 mM 4-MU-(GlcNAc)2 substrate in 80 μL of buffer (0.1 M citric acid and 0.2 M sodium phosphate (pH 6.0)) at 37 °C for 15 min. After incubation, the reaction was stopped by mixing with 100 μL of 0.5 M Na2CO3 buffer. Released 4-MU was quantified with a nano-drop 3000 (Thermo Fischer Scientific).

      1
      Marked elevation of plasma chitotriosidase activity. A novel hallmark of Gaucher disease
      Hollak C E; van Weely S; van Oers M H; Aerts J M
      The Journal of clinical investigation (1994), 93 (3), 1288-92 ISSN:0021-9738.
      Gaucher disease (GD; glucosylceramidosis) is caused by a deficient activity of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase (GC). Clinical manifestations are highly variable and cannot be predicted accurately on the basis of the properties of mutant GC. Analysis of secondary abnormalities, such as elevated plasma levels of some hydrolases, may help to increase insight into the complicated pathophysiology of the disease and could also provide useful disease markers. The recent availability of enzyme supplementation therapy for GD increases the need for markers as early predictors of the efficacy of treatment. We report the finding of a very marked increase in chitotrisidase activity in plasma of 30 of 32 symptomatic type 1 GD patients studied: the median activity being > 600 times the median value in plasma of healthy volunteers. In three GC-deficient individuals without clinical symptoms, only slight increases were noted. Chitotriosidase activity was absent in plasma of three control subjects and two patients. During enzyme supplementation therapy, chitotriosidase activity declined dramatically. We conclude that plasma chitotriosidase levels can serve as a new diagnostic hallmark of GD and should prove to be useful in assessing whether clinical manifestations of GD are present and for monitoring the efficacy of therapeutic intervention.

      Human chitinases and chitinase-like proteins as indicators for inflammation and cancer
      Kzhyshkowska Julia; Gratchev Alexei; Goerdt Sergij
      Biomarker insights (2007), 2 (), 128-46 ISSN:1177-2719.
      Human Glyco_18 domain-containing proteins constitute a family of chitinases and chitinase-like proteins. Chitotriosidase and AMCase are true enzymes which hydrolyse chitin and have a C-terminal chitin-binding domain. YKL-40, YKL-39, SI-CLP and murine YM1/2 proteins possess solely Glyco_18 domain and do not have the hydrolytic activity. The major sources of Glyco_18 containing proteins are macrophages, neutrophils, epithelial cells, chondrocytes, synovial cells, and cancer cells. Both macrophages and neutrophils use the regulated secretory mechanism for the release of Glyco_18 containing proteins. Glyco_18 containing proteins are established biomarkers for human diseases. Chitotriosidase is overproduced by lipid-laden macrophages and is a major marker for the inherited lysosomal storage Gaucher disease. AMCase and murine lectin YM1 are upregulated in Th2-environment, and enzymatic activity of AMCase contributes to asthma pathogenesis. YKL proteins act as soluble mediators for the cell proliferation and migration, and are also involved in rheumatoid arthritis, inflammatory bowel disease, hepatic fibrosis and cirrhosis. Chitotriosidase and YKL-40 reflect the macrophage activation in atherosclerotic plaques. Serum level of YKL-40 is a diagnostic and prognostic marker for numerous types of solid tumors. YKL-39 is a marker for the activation of chondrocytes and the progression of the osteoarthritis in human. Recently identified SI-CLP is upregulated by Th2 cytokine IL-4 as well as by glucocorticoids. This unique feature of SI-CLP makes it an attractive candidate for the examination of individual sensitivity of patients to glucocorticoid treatment and prediction of side effects of glucocorticoid therapy. Human chitinases and chitinase-like proteins are found in tissues and circulation, and can be detected by non-invasive technologies.

      Gaucher cells demonstrate a distinct macrophage phenotype and resemble alternatively activated macrophages
      Boven, Leonie A.; van Meurs, Marjan; Boot, Rolf G.; Mehta, Atul; Boon, Louis; Aerts, Johannes M.; Laman, Jon D.
      American Journal of Clinical Pathology (2004), 122 (3), 359-369CODEN: AJCPAI; ISSN:0002-9173. (American Society of Clinical Pathologists)
      Although the existence of anti-inflammatory alternatively activated macrophages (aaMΦ) has been accepted widely based on in vitro studies, their in vivo location, phenotype, and function still are debated. Gaucher disease (GD) is caused by a genetic deficiency in the lysosomal enzyme glucocerebrosidase and is characterized by accumulation of glycosphingolipids in so-called Gaucher cells (GCs), By using immunohistochem. anal., we investigated whether this results in an aaMΦ phenotype. GCs are macrophage-like cells, expressing acid phosphatase, CD68, CD14, and HLA class II, but not CD11b, CD40, or dendritic cell markers. GCs show infrequent immunoreactivity for mannose receptor. GCs did not express proinflammatory cytokines such as tumor necrosis factor α and monocyte chemoattractant protein 1, but did express the aaMΦ markers CD163, CCL18, and interleukin-1 receptor antagonist. Furthermore, CD36 and signal receptor protein α, involved in lipid uptake, also were obsd. on GCs. Thus, GCs represent a distinctive population of myeloid cells that resemble aaMΦ but differ from previously described in vitro aaMΦ.

      Serum chitotriosidase activity is increased in subjects With atherosclerosis disease
      Artieda, Marta; Cenarro, Ana; Ganan, Alberto; Jerico, Ivonne; Gonzalvo, Carmen; Casado, Juan M.; Vitoria, Isabel; Puzo, Jose; Pocovi, Miguel; Civeira, Fernando
      Arteriosclerosis, Thrombosis, and Vascular Biology (2003), 23 (9), 1645-1652CODEN: ATVBFA; ISSN:1079-5642. (Lippincott Williams & Wilkins)
      Objective- This study was undertaken to analyze the relation between serum activity of chitotriosidase enzyme, a protein synthesized exclusively by activated macrophages, and atherosclerotic lesion extent in subjects with atherothrombotic stroke (ATS) and in subjects with ischemic heart disease (IHD). Methods and Results- We assayed the serum chitotriosidase activity and a common chitotriosidase gene polymorphism that causes deficiency in chitotriosidase activity in 3 Spanish populations, ATS (n=153), IHD (n=124), and control (n=148) subjects.       Identification of a novel acidic mammalian chitinase distinct from chitotriosidase
      Boot, Rolf G.; Blommaart, Edward F. C.; Swart, Erwin; Ghuharali-Van der Vlugt, Karen; Bijl, Nora; Moe, Cassandra; Place, Allen; Aerts, Johannes M. F. G.
      Journal of Biological Chemistry (2001), 276 (9), 6770-6778CODEN: JBCHA3; ISSN:0021-9258. (American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology)
      Chitinases are ubiquitous chitin-fragmenting hydrolases. Recently we discovered the first human chitinase, named chitotriosidase, that is specifically expressed by phagocytes. We here report the identification, purifn., and subsequent cloning of a second mammalian chitinase. This enzyme is characterized by an acidic isoelec. point and therefore named acidic mammalian chitinase (AMCase). In rodents and man the enzyme is relatively abundant in the gastrointestinal tract and is found to a lesser extent in the lung. Like chitotriosidase, AMCase is synthesized as a 50-kDa protein contg. a 39-kDa N-terminal catalytic domain, a hinge region, and a C-terminal chitin-binding domain. In contrast to chitotriosidase, the enzyme is extremely acid stable and shows a distinct second pH optimum around pH 2. AMCase is capable of cleaving artificial chitin-like substrates as well as crab shell chitin and chitin as present in the fungal cell wall. Our study has revealed the existence of a chitinolytic enzyme in the gastrointestinal tract and lung that may play a role in digestion and/or defense.

      Inhibition of acidic mammalian chitinase by RNA interference suppresses ovalbumin-sensitized allergic asthma
      Yang, Ching-Jen; Liu, Yu-Kuo; Liu, Chao-Lin; Shen, Chia-Ning; Kuo, Ming-Ling; Su, Chien-Chang; Tseng, Ching-Ping; Yen, Tzu-Chen; Shen, Chia-Rui
      Human Gene Therapy (2009), 20 (12), 1597-1606CODEN: HGTHE3; ISSN:1043-0342. (Mary Ann Liebert, Inc.)
      Asthma, a chronic helper T cell type 2-mediated inflammatory disease, is characterized by airway hyperresponsiveness and inflammation. Growing evidence suggests that increased expression of acidic mammalian chitinase (AMCase) may play a role in the pathogenesis of asthma. In the present study, we sought to develop an RNA interference approach to suppress allergic asthma in mice through silencing of AMCase expression. Mice sensitized with ovalbumin (OVA) were intratracheally administered a recombinant adeno-assocd. virus expressing short hairpin RNA (rAAV-shRNA) against AMCase. In OVA-sensitized mice, the development of allergic symptoms was significantly assocd. with elevated AMCase expression. After administration of rAAV-shRNA, there was a significant redn. of AMCase expression in the lung and in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF) cells of sensitized mice. Sensitized mice receiving rAAV-shRNA showed a significant improvement in allergic symptoms, including airway hyperresponsiveness (AHR), eosinophil infiltration, eotaxin, interleukin-13 secretion in BALF, and serum OVA-specific IgE level. Our data suggest the hyperexpression of AMCase in asthma can be suppressed by rAAV-mediated shRNA. Silencing AMCase expression by shRNA may be a promising therapeutic strategy in asthma.

      Acidic Mammalian Chitinase in Asthmatic Th2 Inflammation and IL-13 Pathway Activation
      Zhu, Zhou; Zheng, Tao; Homer, Robert J.; Kim, Yoon-Keun; Chen, Ning Yuan; Cohn, Lauren; Hamid, Qutayba; Elias, Jack A.
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2004), 304 (5677), 1678-1682CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      Chitin is a surface component of parasites and insects, and chitinases are induced in lower life forms during infections with these agents.       Polymorphisms and haplotypes of acid mammalian chitinase are associated with bronchial asthma
      Bierbaum Sibylle; Nickel Renate; Koch Anja; Lau Susanne; Deichmann Klaus A; Wahn Ulrich; Superti-Furga Andrea; Heinzmann Andrea
      American journal of respiratory and critical care medicine (2005), 172 (12), 1505-9 ISSN:1073-449X.
      RATIONALE: Chitinases are enzymes that cleave chitin, a polysaccharide contained in many parasites of humans. Recent studies in mouse models of bronchial asthma have shown that acid mammalian chitinase (AMCase) is involved in the pathophysiology of asthma. It acts downstream of interleukin-13; inhibition of AMCase leads to an abrogated T-helper cell 2 inflammation, less bronchial hyperreactivity, and fewer eosinophils. OBJECTIVES: The aim of this study was to identify common genetic variants in human AMCase and to use them to test for association of AMCase with pediatric asthma. METHODS: By sequencing the promotor region and all 11 exons on 30 individuals, 12 high-frequency polymorphisms were identified. Genotyping of six variants in exons and one promotor polymorphism was performed on the following populations by means of restriction fragment length polymorphisms: 322 children with asthma, 270 randomly chosen adult controls, and a pediatric control population consisting of 565 children who, at age 10 yr, had never wheezed and never been diagnosed having asthma. MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS: We identified three known and two new amino acid variants. Analyses by the Armitage's trend test using both control populations showed association of the newly identified variant K17R and the nearby noncoding polymorphism rs3818822 with asthma (p = 0.0031 and p = 0.0003, respectively). In addition, haplotype analyses revealed strong association of haplotypes with the disease (asthma population vs. pediatric control subjects, p < 10(-10)). CONCLUSIONS: This newly described association between AMCase polymorphisms and asthma adds further evidence supporting the involvement of AMCase in the development of asthma.

      Analyzing Airway Inflammation with Chemical Biology: Dissection of Acidic Mammalian Chitinase Function with a Selective Drug-like Inhibitor
      Sutherland, Tara E.; Andersen, Ole A.; Betou, Marie; Eggleston, Ian M.; Maizels, Rick M.; van Aalten, Daan; Allen, Judith E.
      Chemistry & Biology (Cambridge, MA, United States) (2011), 18 (5), 569-579CODEN: CBOLE2; ISSN:1074-5521. (Cell Press)
      Acidic mammalian chitinase (AMCase) is produced in the lung during allergic inflammation and asthma, and inhibition of enzymic activity has been considered as a therapeutic strategy.       Demethylallosamidin, a chitinase inhibitor, suppresses airway inflammation and hyperresponsiveness
      Matsumoto, Takafumi; Inoue, Hiromasa; Sato, Yosuke; Kita, Yoshihiro; Nakano, Takako; Noda, Naotaka; Eguchi-Tsuda, Miyuki; Moriwaki, Atsushi; Kan-o, Keiko; Matsumoto, Koichiro; Shimizu, Takao; Nagasawa, Hiromichi; Sakuda, Shohei; Nakanishi, Yoichi

      Chen, Lei; Zhou, Yong; Qu, Mingbo; Zhao, Yong; Yang, Qing

Structure-based comparison showed that the fully deacetylated chitooligosaccharides mimic the substrate chitooligosaccharides by binding to the active cleft. This work first reports the inhibitory activity and proposed inhibitory mechanism of fully deacetylated chitooligosaccharides. Because the fully deacetylated chitooligosaccharides can be easily derived from chitin, one of the most abundant materials in nature, this work also provides a platform for developing eco-friendly inhibitors against chitinases.

      Screening-based Discovery and Structural Dissection of a Novel Family 18 Chitinase Inhibitor
      Schuettelkopf, Alexander W.; Andersen, Ole A.; Rao, Francesco V.; Allwood, Matthew; Lloyd, Clare; Eggleston, Ian M.; van Aalten, Daan M. F.
      Journal of Biological Chemistry (2006), 281 (37), 27278-27285CODEN: JBCHA3; ISSN:0021-9258. (American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology)
      Family 18 chitinases play key roles in the life cycles of a variety of organisms ranging from bacteria to man. Although several potent natural product chitinase inhibitors have been identified, their chemotherapeutic potential or their use as cell biol. tools is limited due to their size, complex chem., and limited availability.       Functional comparison of recombinant acidic mammalian chitinase with enzyme from murine bronchoalveolar lavage
      Goedken, Eric R.; O'Brien, Robert F.; Xiang, Tao; Banach, David L.; Marchie, Susan C.; Barlow, Eve H.; Hubbard, Stacy; Mankovich, John A.; Jiang, Jianjun; Richardson, Paul L.; Cuff, Carolyn A.; Cherniack, Andrew D.

      Acidic mammalian chitinase (AMCase) is an enzyme that selectively degrades the biopolymer chitin. Several chitinase enzymes are utilized by mammals to hydrolyze chitin encountered by inhalation and ingestion. AMCase is distinct from other mammalian chitinases as its activity is retained in strongly acidic conditions (pH < 2.0). AMCase expression is induced by antigen-induced mouse models of allergic lung inflammation. This protein has also been implicated in the pathogenesis of asthma although its precise role is poorly defined. A novel way to express and purify active murine AMCase is described. It was found that chitinase in BAL from both antigen-challenged and control animals have similar properties in this regard. This strongly supports the notion the same enzyme (AMCase) gives rise to chitinase activity in both challenged and unchallenged animals. Expression of active human AMCase is also described. The methods described in this paper provide a reliable source of recombinant AMCase that can be utilized to expand understanding of AMCase's role in regulating allergic inflammation.

      Relating protein pharmacology by ligand chemistry
      Keiser, Michael J.; Roth, Bryan L.; Armbruster, Blaine N.; Ernsberger, Paul; Irwin, John J.; Shoichet, Brian K.
      Nature Biotechnology (2007), 25 (2), 197-206CODEN: NABIF9; ISSN:1087-0156. (Nature Publishing Group)
      The identification of protein function based on biol. information is an area of intense research. Here the authors consider a complementary technique that quant. groups and relates proteins based on the chem. similarity of their ligands. The authors began with 65,000 ligands annotated into sets for hundreds of drug targets. The similarity score between each set was calcd. using ligand topol. A statistical model was developed to rank the significance of the resulting similarity scores, which are expressed as a min. spanning tree to map the sets together. Although these maps are connected solely by chem. similarity, biol. sensible clusters nevertheless emerged. Links among unexpected targets also emerged, among them that methadone, emetine and loperamide (Imodium) may antagonize muscarinic M3, α2 adrenergic and neurokinin NK2 receptors, resp. These predictions were subsequently confirmed exptl. Relating receptors by ligand chem. organizes biol. to reveal unexpected relationships that may be assayed using the ligands themselves.

      Rules for Identifying Potentially Reactive or Promiscuous Compounds
      Bruns, Robert F.; Watson, Ian A.
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2012), 55 (22), 9763-9772CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      This article describes a set of 275 rules, developed over an 18-yr period, used to identify compds. that may interfere with biol. assays, allowing their removal from screening sets. Reasons for rejection include reactivity (e.g., acyl halides), interference with assay measurements (fluorescence, absorbance, quenching), activities that damage proteins (oxidizers, detergents), instability (e.g., latent aldehydes), and lack of druggability (e.g., compds. lacking both oxygen and nitrogen). The structural queries were profiled for frequency of occurrence in druglike and nondruglike compd. sets and were extensively reviewed by a panel of experienced medicinal chemists. As a means of profiling the rules and as a filter in its own right, an index of biol. promiscuity was developed. The 584 gene targets with screening data at Lilly were assigned to 17 subfamilies, and the no. of subfamilies at which a compd. was active was used as a promiscuity index. For certain compds., promiscuous activity disappeared after sample repurifn., indicating interference from occult contaminants. Because this type of interference is not amenable to substructure search, a "nuisance list" was developed to flag interfering compds. that passed the substructure rules.

      Potent Family-18 Chitinase Inhibitors: X-RAY STRUCTURES, AFFINITIES, AND BINDING MECHANISMS
      Pantoom, Supansa; Vetter, Ingrid R.; Prinz, Heino; Suginta, Wipa

      Six novel inhibitors of Vibrio harveyi chitinase A (VhChiA), a family-18 chitinase homolog, were identified by in vitro screening of a library of pharmacol. active compds. X-ray data and isothermal microcalorimetry showed that the inhibitors occupied the active site of VhChiA in three different binding modes, including single-site binding, independent two-site binding, and sequential two-site binding.       Experimental and computational approaches to estimate solubility and permeability in drug discovery and development settings
      Lipinski, Christopher A.; Lombardo, Franco; Dominy, Beryl W.; Feeney, Paul J.
      Advanced Drug Delivery Reviews (1997), 23 (1-3), 3-25CODEN: ADDREP; ISSN:0169-409X. (Elsevier)
      A review with 50 refs. Exptl. and computational approaches to est. soly. and permeability in discovery and development settings are described. In the discovery setting 'the rule of 5' predicts that poor absorption or permeation is more likely when there are more than 5 H-bond donors, 10 H-bond acceptors, the mol. wt. (MWT) is >500 and the calcd. Log P (CLogP) is >5. Computational methodol. for the rule-based Moriguchi Log P (MLogP) calcn. is described. Turbidimetric soly. measurement is described and applied to known drugs. High throughput screening (HTS) leads tend to have higher MWT and Log P and lower turbidimetric soly. than leads in the pre-HTS era. In the development setting, soly. calcns. focus on exact value prediction and are difficult because of polymorphism. Recent work on linear free energy relationships and Log P approaches are critically reviewed. Useful predictions are possible in closely related analog series when coupled with exptl. thermodn. soly. measurements.

      Hierarchical virtual screening approaches in small molecule drug discovery
      Kumar, Ashutosh; Zhang, Kam Y. J.
      Methods (Amsterdam, Netherlands) (2015), 71 (), 26-37CODEN: MTHDE9; ISSN:1046-2023. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A review. Virtual screening has played a significant role in the discovery of small mol. inhibitors of therapeutic targets in last two decades. Various ligand and structure-based virtual screening approaches are employed to identify small mol. ligands for proteins of interest. These approaches are often combined in either hierarchical or parallel manner to take advantage of the strength and avoid the limitations assocd. with individual methods. Hierarchical combination of ligand and structure-based virtual screening approaches has received noteworthy success in numerous drug discovery campaigns. In hierarchical virtual screening, several filters using ligand and structure-based approaches are sequentially applied to reduce a large screening library to a no. small enough for exptl. testing. In this review, we focus on different hierarchical virtual screening strategies and their application in the discovery of small mol. modulators of important drug targets. Several virtual screening studies are discussed to demonstrate the successful application of hierarchical virtual screening in small mol. drug discovery.

      Comparison of Shape-Matching and Docking as Virtual Screening Tools
      Hawkins, Paul C. D.; Skillman, A. Geoffrey; Nicholls, Anthony
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2007), 50 (1), 74-82CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      Ligand docking is a widely used approach in virtual screening. In recent years a large no. of publications have appeared in which docking tools are compared and evaluated for their effectiveness in virtual screening against a wide variety of protein targets. These studies have shown that the effectiveness of docking in virtual screening is highly variable due to a large no. of possible confounding factors. Another class of method that has shown promise in virtual screening is the shape-based, ligand-centric approach. Several direct comparisons of docking with the shape-based tool ROCS have been conducted using data sets from some of these recent docking publications. The results show that a shape-based, ligand-centric approach is more consistent than, and often superior to, the protein-centric approach taken by docking.
